Unlike previous generations of wireless technology, 5G operates at much higher frequencies, which means it uses a different type of radiation known as millimeter waves. These waves have a much shorter range and are absorbed more quickly by the human body, leading to significant biological impacts.

Numerous studies have shown that even non-ionizing radiation, such as that used in 5G, can have harmful effects. For instance, research from the National Toxicology Program (NTP) found that long-term exposure to radiofrequency radiation, even at levels considered safe by the FCC, was associated with an increased risk of certain types of cancer in lab animals.
